title: Waugh: A lack of rainbows on the Embarras River
text:
Report an error 
About this time 96 years ago a great man-hunt took place in the West Country along the McLeod and Embarras rivers. 
One which Wop May – Edmonton’s legendary air industry pioneer and First World War fighter ace – described as the “most hazardous and dangerous” he had ever been on. 
This coming from the guy who once had the Red Baron on his tail of his Sopwith Camel during a First World War dogfight. 
Before his Royal Air Force squadron leader and high school buddy Roy Brown put the feared German fighter pilot’s Fokker triplane into the Flanders Fields’ mud for good, under orders from Edmonton Police Chief George Hill, May on Sept. 3, 1919 May flew his Curtis Jenny to Edson with police detective James Campbell in what the Edmonton Bulletin called “a new chapter in the history of the rounding up of criminals.” 
Their mission was to “run to earth a gunman” suspected of hiding out somewhere on the Coal Branch, according to newspaper clippings lovingly accumulated by Edmonton aviation historian and Wop May aficionado John Chalmers. 
They were looking for ex-con, “dangerous criminal” and “cold-blooded murderer” John Larsen, who may not have been the sharpest knife in the drawer. Larsen made his get-away after gunning down Edmonton police Constable and war hero Will Nixon following a confrontation on 101 Street by buying a train ticket to Mountain Park. 
Nixon joined the 19th Alberta Dragoons in August 1914 and survived Ypres, Festubert, Givenchy, Vimy, Passchendaale, Amiens and Cambrai before being gassed two days from the Armistice, only to get shot on a peaceful Edmonton street. His funeral cortege down Jasper Ave. stretched for five blocks. 
May dodged telegraph wires landing on Edson’s main street and clipped the village pump taking off. A re-fuelling stop in Wabamun also almost ended in disaster when Wop brushed the tree tops. 
Campbell caught Larson in Cadomin but the hand-cuffed desperado escaped when he jumped from a railway speeder coming down the Grand Trunk Pacific grade from Mercoal. 
He was re-captured two nights later when Campbell set up a sting in a deserted section shack. 
Larson entered the building armed with a survey stake and “looked into the muzzles of the guns” Campbell and an Alberta Provincial Police constable pointed at him. 
“Hunger, fear and the nature of the uninhabited wilderness” all played a part, the Bulletin writer surmised. 
Chief Hill called it “the cleverest piece of detective work.” 
My recent trip to the Coal Branch was nothing like Wop’s. 
Two hours and change in the Jeep, a hike down an over-grown cutline, a short scramble down the steep bank and my fishing dog Penny and I were standing on the gravels of the Embarras River. 
Or what’s left of it. The never-ending drought has been hard on trout creeks all along the Eastern Slopes. 
The Embarras’ bones were showing. 
I have come in search of Athabasca rainbows – Alberta’s unique trout which are the only native rainbow found east of the Continental Divide. 
My first cast of the sweet little small-creek cane-rod I assembled last winter produced a take in a scour below an overhanging alder. 
The next pass of the #14 Bunny Variant resulted in a second take and a hook-up. 
But instead of a beautifully parr-marked and spotted Atha-bow, a pewter-sided grayling danced at the end of the line. 
Arctic grayling are usually more prevalent on the lower sections of this short, sublime river while the upper part has been predominately trout territory in the past. 
Except not this day. The next fish was a grayling. The same with the next and the next as I worked my way downstream, which was not the smartest thing to do because of the clouds of silt the dog and I were kicking up. 
By the time the slanting sun said it was time to go I’m pretty sure I hooked and released 50 fish. 
Of which, curiously, only three were rainbows.
